Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Characterizing climate-induced qualitative changes in plant biopolymer composition and their influence on soil processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The productivity of an ecosystem depends on the recycling of nutrients through the process of decomposition. Decomposition is primarily governed by climate and the chemical composition of plant litter. Traditionally, decomposition rates have been estimated using concentrations of carbon, nitrogen and lignin in the litter. However, the structural characteristics of many hard-to-degrade compounds (biopolymers), including lignins, tannins and cuticular matrices, can dictate overall decomposition rates. The climate in which plants grow can strongly influence the structural properties of these compounds. Climate change thus has the potential to alter decomposition both directly, by changing temperature and moisture, and also indirectly, by changing the structural attributes of biopolymers in plant litter, in ways that are not factored into traditional nutrient cycling models. This project has three long-term goals. The first goal is to learn how growing season temperature and moisture availability affect the diversity and chemical properties of biopolymers that govern decomposition of plant litter. The second goal is to understand how environmental conditions interact with the chemical composition of litter to affect decomposition and nutrient cycling. The third goal is to develop and test models of decomposition that incorporate new knowledge of the roles of climate and biopolymer properties. The investigators will test these hypotheses using six plant species from the Boston-Area Climate Experiment, which exposes patches of old fields with tree seedlings to twelve possible future climates.

Results from this project will improve predictions of carbon and nitrogen cycling in a changing climate. The results will have application beyond soil nutrient dynamics, as tannins are relevant to food quality (as antioxidants), fodder quality and herbivory (as deterrents). The project will provide undergraduates with opportunities for creative inquiry and a new course offering, and will develop a summer course for in-service K-12 teachers and non-formal educators. The project also will provide learning and research experiences to high school students and students from the minority college in the state through the South Carolina Life program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Projected increase in temperature and frequent droughts pose stressful climatic conditions for plant growth potentially affecting food, fodder and fuel production. A comprehensive understanding of the responses of plants to stressful climatic conditions is critical to develop management practices that would enhance plant productivity and soil carbon storage. A majority of carbon in soils is directly or indirectly derived from plant roots. Thus, the chemistry of root tissues is an important parameter that regulate their potential to contribute to soil carbon. Adverse climatic conditions would alter root tissue chemical composition and root-fungal associations that would modify their potential to contribute to soil carbon. Root tissues contain many polymeric compounds such as suberin, lignin and tannins that help them to defend against pests and pathogens while concurrently allowing them to maximize their resource uptake functions. Using advanced spectroscopic and spectrometric techniques, I examined the changes in the structural and metabolic components of root tissues subjected to warming, drought and elevated carbon oxide conditions. Roots that were subjected to elevated CO2 and warming not only had higher content of suberin but these treatments also differentially altered the chemical composition of suberin. Plant tissues subjected to drought and warming treatments had greater amount of metabolites such as amino acids, organic acids and phenolic acids that allow plants to mitigate the climatic stress. The greater amount of tannins produced in these tissues under drought and warmer climates also decreased the amount of nitrogen that was re-absorbed back to the plant system. Plant tissues subjected to drought and warmer conditions with greater amount of recalcitrant compounds had lower rate of decomposition as they were energetically less favorable for microbial decomposers. This would slow nutrient cycling in ecosystems affecting plant productivity and soil carbon storage under future climates.

This research has many implications beyond environmental sciences. The finer level characterization of biopolymers would contribute to our understanding of the enzymatic degradation of plant biomass for bioenergy production, and facilitate the development of sustainable bioenergy crops. The results would also potentially inform land management practices in degraded ecosystems (both agricultural and forested landscapes) through plant root mediated soil carbon storage. The research involved collaboration with multiple institutions and trained 6 high school students, 12 undergraduates, two graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow. Among these students more than 50% belonged to women researchers and also included students from minority groups. The analytical methods optimized in the project were incorporated as part of the curriculum in a graduate course taught by the PI at Clemson University (PLPA 8090). Forty-seven graduate students were trained on these methods (2012-2015). The results were disseminated through publications, presented as talks and posters in national and regional conferences and informal meetings with general public.
